facts.text: Ramchandar Jat originally owned Annas 10/8 share in Mauza Tamalawadi.

anchor.surface_text: One Ramchandar Jat originally owned Annas -10/8 share in Mauza Tamalawadi while the rest belonged to others.

facts.text: Ramchandar executed a simple mortgage deed on July 27, 1920, in favour of Seth Ram Jiwan and two minors Ram Narain and Radhey Sham.

anchor.surface_text: Ramchandar executed a simple mortgage deed on July 27, 1920, in favour of Seth Ram Jiwan and two. minors Ram Narain and Radhey Sham.

facts.text: The plaintiffs-respondents are the representatives of the mortgagees.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs. respondents are the representatives of the mortgagees.

facts.text: Defendant-appellant purchased Annas 5/4 share belonging to the other shareholders on August 27, 1926.

anchor.surface_text: On August 27, 1926, the defendant-appellant -purchased Annas -/5/4 share belonging to the other share holders in the village.

facts.text: Appellant brought a suit against Ramchandar for profits and obtained a decree against him.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant brought a suit against Ramchandar who was lambardar of the village for profits, in which 9, decree was passed against Ramchandar.

facts.text: In execution of the decree, the appellant purchased the entire Annas 10/8 share of Ramchandar about the year 1932.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of that decree the appellant purchased the entire Annas -/10/8 share of Ramchandar in the village about the year 1932.

facts.text: Appellant became the owner of the entire village subject to the mortgage of the respondents on Annas 5/4 share.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the appellant became the owner of the entire village subject to the mortgage of the respondents on Annas -/5/4 share therein.

facts.text: Respondents sued Ramchandar on the basis of their mortgage-deed on July 27, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: On July 27, 1932, the respondents sued Ramchandar on the basis of their mortgage-deed and a preliminary decree for sale was passed in March, 1937.

facts.text: Preliminary decree for sale passed in March 1937; appellant was a party to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: and a preliminary decree for sale was passed in March, 1937. To this suit the appellant was also a party.

facts.text: Property sold and purchased by respondents on March 1, 1940; confirmed on April 12, 1940; sale certificate granted.

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary decree was followed by a final decree and thereafter the property was put to sale and was purchased by the respondents on March 1, 1940. This sale was companyfirmed on April 12, 1940, and a sale certificate was granted to the respondents.

facts.text: By 1940, respondents owned Annas 5/4 share, appellant owned Annas 10/8 share.

anchor.surface_text: So by the year 1940 the respondents were the owners of Annas -/5/4 share in the village while the appellant was the owner of Annas -/10/8 share.

facts.text: Ramchandar held sir land in certain khasras with total area of 252-49 acres.

anchor.surface_text: Ramchandar Jat held sir land in certain khasras with a total area of 252-49 acres.

facts.text: After sale of his share to appellant, Ramchandar became ex-proprietary tenant of his sir land; ejected sometime in 1936, lands came into possession of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the sale of Ramchandars share to the appellant, Ramchandar became an ex-proprietary tenant of his sir land. Thereafter Ramchandar was ejected from his exproprietary tenancy sometime in 1936 and the lands came into possession of the appellant.

facts.text: Certain lands nominally recorded as Muafi Khairati in name of Ramchandar's mother but in possession of Ramchandar; ejected and came into possession of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There were certain other lands which were numberinally recorded as Muafi Khairati in the name of Ramchandars mother but were actually in the possession of Ramchandar. It appears that Ramchandar was ejected from these lands also and they came into, the possession of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant as lambardar came into possession of certain other lands by surrender or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Further the appellant as a lambardar came into possession of certain other lands by surrender or otherwise.

facts.text: Respondents filed suit for partition before Sub-Divisional Officer, Hard, in 1942, claiming half share in lands of Ramchandar and mother, and share in lambardar lands as accession to mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed a suit for partition before the Sub- Divisional Officer, Hard, in 1942. In that suit they claimed half share in the lands of Ramchandar and his mother which came into. the possession of the appellant.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer rejected respondents' contention on October 20, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1943, the Sub-Divisional Officer passed an order which in effect rejected the companytention of the respondents and accepted the plea of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondents filed present suit for declaration in civil court in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents filed the present suit for a declaration in the civil companyrt in 1944 claiming that they were entitled to a proportionate share in the lands specified in the plaint.

facts.text: Trial court decreed part of respondents' claim, dismissed rest.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of issues were framed by the trial companyrt, which decreed a part of the claim put forward by the respondents but dismissed the rest.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal for one-half share in sir plots of Ramchandar, one-third in mother's lands and lambardar lands subject to payment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was allowed so far as the respondents claim to one-half share in the sir plots held by Ramchandar was companycerned. Further, they were allowed one-third share in the lands held by the mother of Ramchandar and also in certain other lands which came into the possession of the appellant as lambardar subject to payment of certain amounts.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 28, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court, in First Appeal No. 107 of 1946.

facts.text: Appellant contends mortgage deed of 1920 did not include sir plots or mother's plots, nor suit or sale certificate.

facts.text: Mortgage was of half share Annas 5/4 out of 10/8, area 678.31 acres, including khudkashat, etc., and all rights appertaining to the village.

anchor.surface_text: I do hereby mortgage without possession half share -/5/4, five annas and four pies, area 678.31 acres, jama-sarkar Rs. 326/10/8 together with khudkashat, chhotaghas, big shrubs, abadi, gair abadi, cultivated and that lying vacant, and the rights and privileges appertaining to water, forests, chahat, gardens, and right of cultivation, malguzari and trees of every kind whether giving fruits or numberfruits and prohibited and unprohibited wood with entire rights and prvileges appertaining to the village.

facts.text: After appellant purchased Ramchandar's share in 1932, Ramchandar became ex-proprietary tenant of sir under s.49 Tenancy Act; ejected 1936, land to lambardar appellant, becoming accession to mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Now what happened after the mortgage deed in favour of the respondents was that the appellant purchased the entire -/10/8 share of Ramchandar subject to the mortgage of the respondents in 1932. At that time Ramchandar became an ex- proprietary tenant of his entire sir relating to this share under s. 49 of the Tenancy Act. In 1936 Ramchandar was ejected from the ex-proprietary tenancy which came in the possession of the appellant as lambardar

issues.text: Whether the mortgage deed of 1920 included proprietary rights in sir land pertaining to the mortgaged share of Annas -/5/4

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant before us is that the mortgage deed of 1920 -which is the basis of the title of the respondents did number include the sir plots in the possession of, Ramchandar number the plots of Ramchandars mother. Nor were these plots included in the suit which was brought by the respondents on the basis of the mortgage- deed. Further, the sale certificate also did number include these plots, though some other plots were mentioned therein. Therefore, the respondents were number entitled to these plots as accession to the mortgage.

issues.text: Whether sanction under s. 50 of the Central Provinces Tenancy Act was required for the simple mortgage to affect proprietary rights in sir land

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to ss. 49 and 50 of the Central Provinces Tenancy Act, No. 1 of 1920  hereinafter called the Tenancy Act  which deal with transfer of sir land. Under s. 49  1  a proprietor who temporarily or permanently loses whether under a decree or order of a civil companyrt or by transfer or otherwise his right to occupy any portion of his sir land as a proprietor shall at the date of such loss, become an occupancy. tenant except where he has obtained a sanction under s. 50 of the Tenancy Act.

issues.text: Whether the plaint in the mortgage suit included sir land pertaining to the mortgaged share

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to the plaint in the mortgage suit we find that the property subject to the mortgage is mentioned in para. 2 thereof inexactly the same terms as in the mortgage deed. In para. 13 it is again recited that the mortgagor mortgaged -/5/4 share out of his -/10/8 share. Paragraph 13 then goes on to say that on the date of the mortgage, the mortgagor had certain khudkashat and chhotaghas lands and both cultivating and proprietary rights in them pertaining to half share only were liable to be sold.

issues.text: Whether the sale certificate conveyed proprietary rights in sir land pertaining to the purchased share

anchor.surface_text: Then companying to the sale certificate we find that it certifies that the respondents had purchased -/5/4 share in the village with abadi, khudkashat, chhotaghas and all rights pertaining to the share. It is true that khudkashat and chhotaghas are specifically mentioned in the sale certificate but the words all rights pertaining to the share appearing in the sale certificate would include such proprietary rights in the sir land as belonged to the share mentioned in the sale certificate.

issues.text: Whether the sir land became an accession to the mortgaged property under s. 70 of the Transfer of Property Act upon extinction of Ramchandar's ex-proprietary tenancy

anchor.surface_text: At that time Ramchandar became an ex- proprietary tenant of his entire sir relating to this share under s. 49 of the Tenancy Act. In 1936 Ramchandar was ejected from the ex-proprietary tenancy which came in the possession of the appellant as lambardar and has apparently since then remained in his possession. The case of the respondents is that in 1936 their mortgage was subsisting and the sir land which thus came into the possession of the appellant on the extinction of the ex-proprietary tenancy became an accession to the mortgage

issues.text: Whether the lands recorded in the name of Ramchandar's mother entitled the respondents to a share as accession

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the lands in the name of Ramchandars mother. It appears that these lands came into the possession of Ramchandar after the mortgage but before the institution of the mortgage suit. They were numberinally recorded in the name of his mother and in 1932 after his entire share was purchased by the appellant lie was recorded as an occupancy tenant of these lands. Later the appellant came into possession of them apparently as a lambardar.

issues.text: Whether the respondents' claim to the lands in Ramchandar's mother's name was barred by Order 11 Rule 2 CPC

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that the claim of the respondents to these lands was barred by 0. 11, r. 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, because they were number specified in the plaint based on the mortgage deed of 1920. Reliance in this companynection is placed on Hazarilal v. Hazarimal  1  and Seth Manakchand v. Chaube Manoharlal  2 . These cases in our opinion do number apply, because they are cases of foreclosure while in A. I. R. 1923 Nag. 130, A.I.R. 1944 P.C 46, the present case the respondents suit was for sale of the share mortgaged with them.

issues.text: Whether the respondents are entitled to a share in lands that came into possession of the appellant as lambardar

anchor.surface_text: This leaves certain lands which came into the possession of the appellant as a lambardar in the ordinary companyrse of management. holdings.text: The mortgage deed of 1920 included proprietary rights in sir land pertaining to the mortgaged Annas 5/4 share as it mortgaged the entire share without specific exclusion of sir.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that sir is number specifically mentioned in the mortgage but as the mortgage was of the entire -/5/4 share out of -/10/8 share it will include  unless there is a specific exclusion of sir  the area of sir also pertaining to the share mortgaged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgage of entire share includes all pertaining rights including sir unless excluded; descriptive terms precautionary.

holdings.text: No sanction under s.50 Central Provinces Tenancy Act required for simple mortgage of sir rights as no loss of occupancy right occurs without possession transfer.

anchor.surface_text: But the mortgage in this case is a simple mortgage and there was numbertransfer of possession under it. Therefore the proprietor Ramchandar never lost his right to occupy his sir land by this mortgage

holdings.reasoning_summary: Simple mortgage without possession does not trigger s.49 loss of occupancy; s.50 sanction only for transfers causing permanent loss without reservation.

holdings.text: Plaint in mortgage suit included sir land pertaining to mortgaged share by describing property in same terms as deed and reciting mortgaged share.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to the plaint in the mortgage suit we find that the property subject to the mortgage is mentioned in para. 2 thereof inexactly the same terms as in the mortgage deed. In para. 13 it is again recited that the mortgagor mortgaged -/5/4 share out of his -/10/8 share.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint mirrors deed; no need to specify sir explicitly as share includes it; precautionary mentions do not limit.

holdings.text: Sale certificate conveyed proprietary rights in sir land via 'all rights pertaining to the share'.

anchor.surface_text: Then companying to the sale certificate we find that it certifies that the respondents had purchased -/5/4 share in the village with abadi, khudkashat, chhotaghas and all rights pertaining to the share. It is true that khudkashat and chhotaghas are specifically mentioned in the sale certificate but the words all rights pertaining to the share

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit 'all rights pertaining to share' encompasses sir proprietary rights belonging to share.

holdings.text: Sir land became accession to mortgaged property under s.70 Transfer of Property Act upon extinction of Ramchandar's ex-proprietary tenancy in 1936 while mortgage subsisting.

anchor.surface_text: Now what happened after the mortgage deed in favour of the respondents was that the appellant purchased the entire -/10/8 share of Ramchandar subject to the mortgage of the respondents in 1932. At that time Ramchandar became an ex- proprietary tenant of his entire sir relating to this share under s. 49 of the Tenancy Act. In 1936 Ramchandar was ejected from the ex-proprietary tenancy which came in the possession of the appellant as lambardar

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extinction made land khudkashat in lambardar mortgagor's possession; legal accession as mortgage subsisting; s.70 applies.

holdings.text: Respondents entitled to share in lands recorded in Ramchandar's mother's name as possession held for entire proprietary body.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the lands in the name of Ramchandars mother. It appears that these lands came into the possession of Ramchandar after the mortgage but before the institution of the mortgage suit. They were numberinally recorded in the name of his mother and in 1932 after his entire share was purchased by the appellant lie was recorded as an occupancy tenant of these lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lands pertained to share; appellant's possession as lambardar for whole body includes respondents' share.

holdings.text: Claim to mother's lands not barred by O.11 r.2 CPC as suit was for sale of mortgaged share, not foreclosure, and no need to specify all pertaining lands.

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that the claim of the respondents to these lands was barred by 0. 11, r. 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, because they were number specified in the plaint based on the mortgage deed of 1920. Reliance in this companynection is placed on Hazarilal v. Hazarimal  1  and Seth Manakchand v. Chaube Manoharlal  2 . These cases in our opinion do number apply, because they are cases of foreclosure while in A. I. R. 1923 Nag. 130, A.I.R. 1944 P.C 46, the present case the respondents suit was for sale of the share mortgaged with them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes foreclosure precedents; sale suits for shares include unspecified pertaining lands at suit time.

holdings.text: Respondents entitled to proportionate share in lambardar management lands subject to payment of expenses.

The concept of Section 69 CPLRA 1917 regarding khudkashat provides the legal ground for the holding that the mortgage of the entire share includes proprietary rights in sir land absent specific exclusion.

Section 69 Central Provinces Land Revenue Act 1917 with reference to khudkashat (self-cultivated/sir land) addresses the issue of whether proprietary rights in sir land are included in the mortgage of the share.
The statutory definition of sir land supports the holding by providing the legal meaning relevant to inclusion of proprietary rights absent exclusion.
The definition of sir land in Section 2(17) addresses the core question in the issue regarding proprietary rights in sir land.

anchor.surface_text: Now what happened after the mortgage deed in favour of the respondents was that the appellant purchased the entire -/10/8 share of Ramchandar subject to the mortgage of the respondents in 1932. At that time Ramchandar became an ex- proprietary tenant of his entire sir relating to this share under s. 49 of the Tenancy Act. In 1936 Ramchandar was ejected from the ex-proprietary tenancy which came in the possession of the appellant as lambardar

This leaves certain lands which came into the possession of the appellant as a lambardar in the ordinary course of management. The respondents would clearly be entitled to a share in these lands also on payment

This brings us to the lands in the name of Ramchandars mother. It appears that these lands came into the possession of Ramchandar after the mortgage but before the institution of the mortgage suit. They were numberinally recorded in the name of his mother and in 1932 after his entire share was purchased by the appellant lie was recorded as an occupancy tenant of these lands.

This leaves certain lands which came into the possession of the appellant as a lambardar in the ordinary course of management. The respondents would clearly be entitled to a share in these lands also on payment
